awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  Optical Sensing Patch for Early Detection of Pressure Ulcers
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project, if successful, will be a major reduction in the prevalence of pressure ulcers achieved through their detection at the earliest stage. More commonly known as bedsores, pressure ulcers are debilitating wounds that prevalently affect bed-bound patients and wheelchair users, estimated at 2.5 million annually. In addition to pain and suffering, pressure ulcers may lead to infection and increased mortality, and they impose a $10 billion burden on the US healthcare system every year. The current standard of care for at-risk patients relies on periodic skin assessments and body repositioning, but research shows that this treatment has limited impact. This engineering project will generate scientific evidence of the body's response to prolonged pressure, which will engage industry stakeholders and investors toward the commercialization of a smart sensing patch capable of detecting pressure ulcers, and the project will enable future pre-clinical and clinical validation studies necessary for FDA clearance and product adoption by hospitals. Importantly, this project will also provide substantial entrepreneurial training and field experience to an engineering graduate who will further develop the commercialization aspects of the technology.

The proposed project will generate groundbreaking knowledge in the field of applied optical imaging and biomedical engineering by imaging and describing mathematically the optical changes occurring in human skin and underlying tissues after exposure to prolonged pressure in a large variety of individuals. To achieve this goal, the team will use a wearable, non-invasive optical patch applied to the sacral area that is known to be at risk of pressure ulcer development in bed-bound patients. No other imaging technology has yet provided quantitative evidence regarding the response of the body to prolonged pressure that may ultimately lead to pressure ulcers; therefore, the outcome of this project will solve a significant technical barrier in this field. Data generated by this study will also inform the technical features of a flexible and disposable smart patch optimized for both cost and performance to facilitate future commercialization efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

NSF Award#: 1919269

Project Title: PFI-TT: Optical Sensing Patch for Early Detection of Pressure Ulcers

Recipient Organization: University of Houston

Project/Grant Period: 08/01/2019 – 01/31/23

Principal Investigators: Luca Pollonini (PI), Jamison Kovach (co-PI)

Pressure Ulcers (PUs), commonly known as bedsores, are skin wounds that result from prolonged pressure over bony prominences (e.g., lower back, heels, shoulders). Bed-bound patients and wheelchair users are especially prone to developing PUs due to their inability to change posture and move pressure away from bone prominences, and thus they must rely on nursing staff to prevent such injuries. However, this approach has been shown to have a limited preventative benefit, especially in clinical settings where nurses have competing priorities within extremely demanding shifts. To minimize the incidence of PUs in the healthcare setting, we propose developing a patch-shaped wearable sensor that detects PUs before it becomes visible to the human eye by monitoring any alteration occurring in tissues over bony prominences.

In this project, we recruited a cohort of healthy individuals to assess whether our optical sensing patch could detect changes in sacral tissues over the course of two hours, which is the standard of care frequency of patient repositioning in acute care settings. Results of this experimental activity showed that changes in sacral tissues under body-weight pressure can be tracked in-vivo and in real time with an optical sensing patch based on near-infrared spectroscopy, and that such smart sensor can be ergonomically integrated in a foam pad for long-term wear during bedside monitoring. We also proved that the effect of pressure on the optical properties of the tissue can be modeled with both analytical and imaging methods, and this project generated the first normative dataset to be used in future clinical studies. To our knowledge, this is the first time that direct measurements of tissue status have been performed in such a realistic scenario (i.e., subjects laid immobile in bed for two consecutive hours).

In addition, we determined that the proposed optical sensing patch can be manufactured within an acceptable cost range for market adoption, without compromising its scientific value. To enhance the translational potential of this technology, we engaged with a cohort of nursing professionals to identify the key design attributes for effectively communicating the increased risk of a PU development. The outcome of this activity showed that the deployment of the proposed technology in clinical settings would successfully integrate in the nursing workflow and provide a beneficial support to the management of PU, rather than adversely disrupting their nursing duties.

In summary, the outcomes of this project provided scientific and technical evidence that the proposed optical sensing technology is sufficiently mature for subsequent translational research and commercialization steps, such as the pursue of small-business funds as well as other capitalization efforts aimed at creating a viable product that successfully fits the PU management market.
